posts.name: iRobot_
posts.cooked:
Hi,

I have a fundamental gap in knowledge regarding whether or not to reset the gyro to 0/180 depending on the alliance we are on. We are using AdvtangeScope’s base swerve drive as the foundation for our project and have made very few changes to it the swerve logic.

A little context, the starting position during auto will have the gyro 0 physically facing the drive alliance. Meaning, without any PathPlanner calls to resetpose(), pressing forward on the joystick will always make forward drive towards the driverstation.

A way around this, to me, would be to set the gyro angle to be 180 if we are on blue alliance, correct? However, here @gdefender ’s comment would suggest that we should not do this at all.

WPILib doesn’t really mention setting the gyro’s position, which mean’s the linked comment above is probably accurate. But WPILib does make mention of inverting joysticks here

I guess what I am looking for is a little guidance for best practices on what I need to do (if anything) to joysticks, gyro, etc if we are running with PathPlanner’s AutoBuilder and without (for drivers practice)

Thanks in advance,

link_counts.title: Starting a match at an angle
Coordinate System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Generally, the red alliance wall is considered the highest positive x value, so anything pointing there is 0 degrees, but if you want normal driver controls from red alliance, you’ll want to put 180 as forward.

posts.name: John Slagel
posts.cooked: We have a button for the driver to “reset orientation”. When the button is pressed, we reset the gyro so that from now on, pressing “forward” goes forward relative to the current orientation. So you turn the robot in the direction you consider “forward” and press the button. We also reset the orientation at the start of auto and start our robot facing forward on the field. This button is useful when testing in the shop, when there is no field.

I think you and @gdefender are talking about 2 different things. You are talking about what heading to reset your robot’s to. And his post is talking about what to reset when resetting the heading of the robot.

Firstly, what to reset. I think the best way here is to not do any thing with your gyro. Don’t reset it, and don’t grab any data directly from it other than when you update your odometry. Only use the data from the odometry, and use your odometry to reset the position and heading when needed. Your odometry will handle all the offset things about your gyro.

Then the heading stuff. Just make sure your robot is facing the right direction in the advantage scope and then invert the x and y  velocity input from your controller when you are on the red alliance. You can get what alliance you are in by calling the DriverStation.getAlliance() in your code.

Hope this could be helpful to you.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I recommend using the always blue origin strategy, as I noted in my other comments and on the WPILib page (that I authored.) Don’t reset your orientation so red becomes (0, 0) when you are on the red alliance, just flip the controls.

This year you can probably get away with origin follows alliance since the field is basically rotated , as long as you’re not doing global pose estimation with AprilTags. But if you go that route, there’s nothing to invert or reset, it just acts the same from the driver’s perspective.

PathPlanner recommends you create all of your autos on the blue side, and use it’s feature to mirror the paths to red . As noted in the comment “THE ORIGIN WILL REMAIN ON THE BLUE SIDE”

HEFZZJM:

I think you and @gdefender are talking about 2 different things.

I disagree, we are talking about the same thing.

HEFZZJM:

Firstly, what to reset.

I recommend you don’t reset anything. Blue should always be the origin.

HEFZZJM:

Invert the x and y velocity input from your controller when you are on the blue alliance

This is a little confusing, but mostly accurate. Pushing up on the controller is negative. You want up to be negative when you’re on the RED alliance, so it’s technically correct, but differs from the way it’s explained in the documentation .

posts.cooked:
gdefender:

This is a little confusing, but mostly accurate. Pushing up on the controller is negative. You want up to be negative when you’re on the RED alliance, so it’s technically correct, but differs from the way it’s explained in the documentation .

You are right. I wasn’t checking the map while writing this, I thought red was the left bottom corner of the map. I’m sorry for the confusion I brought here.

gdefender:

I recommend you don’t reset anything. Blue should always be the origin.

And you are right about this, too. I had thought I was talking about setting the robot pose at the beginning of the match, but I didn’t express clearly about this.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Sure. That’s a setting in PathPlanner, so there’s nothing to do in your code other than hook up the method to reset odomentry image 696×133 3.4 KB

image 696×133 3.4 KB

image 696×133 3.4 KB
, I manually reseted that every time in my command before. I didn’t know I could do that. Thanks for pointing out that.

posts.name: iRobot_
posts.cooked:
So after getting back and testing, all we did was flip the joysticks - which worked. Uncovered some other issues along the way, but I think we are in a good spot!

Thank you!!
